Inflation remains high enough for a final 50 bps rise this year

So in the end this was pretty accurate with a 6:3 split in favour of 0.5%, although the two voting to keep rates lower opted to stay at 3%, while one member voted for 0.75%
Currently at 3 % announcement expected on 15th December that will include a further rise
It's down to the wire Economics Fans. Make your final guesses.
Cycle end with a small increase synchronized with calendar.
All in.

Going all the way now. There were a few murmurings last week that if inflation peaks the MPC might even consider dropping rates. But with food price inflation now up to 12.4% a further rise now looks inevitable
I think there's no real path to lowering it, so I will set those odds to zero and distribute those points elsewhere.

Bank of England to raise Bank Rate by 50 bps in Dec, peak at 4.25% in Q1: Reuters poll - Nov 23, https://www.reuters.com/markets/rates-bonds/bank-england-raise-bank-rate-by-50-bps-dec-peak-425-q1-2022-11-23/
(Forgot to update my forecast, see below)
After Silvana Tenreyro (see below https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1545082 ), a second member of the BoE MPC has voiced concerns for a further increase of interest rates:
Small adjustment, after October inflation coming in hotter than expected at 11.1%: https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/inflationandpriceindices/timeseries/d7g7/mm23

Recession, budget crisis and explosion of residential mortgage cost for the housing markets will likely restrict BoE's wiggle room, despite record official inflation of October 2022 (and probably even worse perceived inflation and eroding inflation expectations). Nevertheless, raising interest rates will be a narrow rope walk between not enough and too much at the BoE's final 2022 session, likely influenced mostly by most recent data points of early December.

I should have checked back on this one after the Nov 3 meeting. The increase to .75 means it all-but-guaranteed we'll be over 3.25. The US is at 3.75-4 and the BOE increased by .75 last time. There is a chance they slow down to a .5 increase, but it see it as very unlikely they will slow all the way down to .25. If they wanted to do that, they likely would have stayed with a .5 increase last time to hold a stead hand rather than creating whiplash in the rate of increase.

Checking against my own rationale a month ago I have a similar view as the circumstances still seem to fit; there is still some time before the final meeting which will allow more information on the effects of previous hikes, and any sign of inflation peaking combined with new government policies (same government, just a different PM with new policies as the old ones were so blatantly failing…) should lead to more circumspect outcome from BoE. There’s room for 0.25% increase within band 4 and I tending to a split decision in favour of this compared to 0.5%
Updating my previous rationale below (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1544560 )
This is still way too uncertain, it would seem...

A further move higher looks almost inevitable, but whether it will be 0.25% or 0.5% I find much harder to predict. Based on the November outcome I think it will be a split decision and a close call between the two, but I'm leaning with the crowd a little.
Difficult one this.
I think it will be close call between 3.25 and 3.5%. Having read a few other opinions I’m not as confident to stay at 3.25%, so I’m moving towards the crowd view a little more.

So, at 3.0% as of today. This is still a tough nut, and I think a mere 25bps hike in the next meeting is far from unthinkable; in contrast with the Fed and the US, where nothing seems to be breaking yet, here something is breaking, namely the home mortgage market.

Up to 3% now. Next update is on 15 Dec. Expectations is it will increase again. It’s unlikely to only go up by 0.25% if they need to increase again so, most likely over that. Of course if they postpone the next meeting or have to increase it will the question will close at 3% so have to keep some likelihood for that.

I'm expecting a split decision today in favour of 0.75% against 0.5% (65:35 split). This would rule out the first three bins.At the final meeting I believe the BoE will be more cautious about increasing further and will hold or add 0.25% (30:70 odds). This would fit bin 4. Next option would be a higher rise in December, for bin 5.If they opt for 0.5% today then I think 0.5% also becomes more likely in December, still in bin 4.

US is now at 3.75-4 but signaling it will slow down the increases. I could see BOE either holding their .5 increases and just ramping up slower or making the jump to .75. I'm going to leave it a toss up.

75bps and 50bps seem relatively unanimous amongst banks. Fiscal dominance is no longer a concern after Truss's dismissal. Inflation remains high and extremely concerning. £ is historically very weak and rate increases will appreciate its value.
There is still significant uncertainly, although expectations of a jumbo-hike of 100bps in November seem to have been ruled out:
Lowering the odds following Truss’s exit and the backtracking of her inflationary mini-budget policies.

I still see it as very likely that BoE will stay at .5 increased for a longer period and follow the more rapid movements of the US Fed. I have to respect the markets thinking a .75 increase is going to happen though, which is certainly possible given we've increased from increased of .25 to .5 this year. What would be interesting is what would happen after a .75 - the natural thing would be another .75, but that would put it at 3.75, which is higher than the current US rate (though might not be after the next meetings. Another path would be a drop to a .5 increase (or lower), which would send a signal that the curbing is nearing an end, but I think BoE is hesitant to send that signal until inflation actually cools off. I guess we'll learn a lot more when we nee what the US Fed does on Nov 1, if they keep going up quickly, BOE might follow.
Backing off slightly, as the markets appear to be expecting +1% in November. I think 0.75% is more likely but we are living in very unpredictable times ...

For all the recent uncertainty, I still think we are on course for something close to 3.25%. The Bank of England is in a difficult position (partly self-inflicted), trying to make the smallest interventions to stabilise inflation reactively rather than pre-emptively. They missed the chance to increase rates higher in response to the now-abandoned mini budget, and even allowing for mutterings from Bailey I think they are now likely to repeat the move or increase no more than 0.75% in November; the new Chancellor's reversal of policies has helped ease borrowing rates down slightly, the forecasted peak has shifted lower for mid-2023 and the BofE will not want to compound problems for mortgage owners short term. I think thier 'wait and see' approach will prevent a major rise above 3.25% by year end, but allowing for more volatility to come.
Lowering a tad following recent government u-turns that may apply less pressure on the bank of england to massively raise rates.

All eyes are now on the Bank of England, with money markets now seeing a 66% chance that it will raise rates by 75 basis points on Nov. 3 after pricing indicated a near certainty of such a rise just a couple of weeks ago. - Reuters, Oct 17, https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/uk-gilts-rally-ahead-expected-new-u-turn-fiscal-plans-2022-10-17/
BOE governor Andew Bailey is talking up the chances of a big increase in November: https://www.ft.com/content/e4c1191e-b085-4929-87e8-ae8c4f1d33d9
There are 2 meetings left. The chaos of the last week means higher chance or higher increases. Looks like everyone it upping their forecasts.
Here is Bloomberg, today (Oct 12) - https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-10-12/bank-of-england-chief-economist-signals-significant-rate-rises :
Two more meetings. Currently at 2.25% - way behind the US which is at 3-3.25% - so plenty of room to go up.

The BofE had reason to push rates up by 0.75% at the last meeting but chose 0.5%. They were also expected to raise rates at an emergency meeting to respond to the shock of the mini-budget, but didn’t (opting instead to buy gilts and bonds to avoid credit contagion risk). Markets have partially stabilised since, and I think they will continue to make cautious interventions by raising rates by 0.5% again in November, followed by a similar rise (or 0.25%) in December. More than this and they could do more harm than good, pushing household costs over the brink for many via variable mortgage rates. If inflation peaks before the December meeting they may hold back at 3-3.25% in the short term to allow room to move further next year. Here’s hoping…

At least one hike >0.5% is likely. I'd expect .75% to be the most likely Nov. number. Basically I would put the expected value of each meeting's hike at ~.63% for a total of about a 1.25% increase (getting rates to 3.5%. But the risk is far more weighted to the high side. It'd take an extreme crisis to shift it in the other direction. And even then, some financial crises might mean faster raises -- because the balance sheet operations required to combat a crisis are effectively loosening and so require faster tightening on the interest rate side.
The tax cut reversal lowers the need for large rate hikes: https://www.ft.com/content/29ebdd94-8c13-48fa-8718-4c86cce902a8
Thank you Liz Truss!
The only way is up!
What can be said, pound in free fall and Bank of England needs to act to bring down inflation
Expecting at least one .75% hike at the next two meetings now, in response to the inflationary impact of the mini budget.

Given today's market movement [ https://twitter.com/EdConwaySky/status/1574784254361337869?s=20&t=2wBIVRDfrRrVr3lJYDdN6w ] and signals from BOE that it is not afraid to adjust rates, I suspect we could be over 3.25 in November, and it now seems extremely unlikely to be below that by end of year. The only scenarios I see where it isn't are:

Kwarteng’s tax cuts will force ‘significant’ interest rate rises by Bank of England - The Guardian, today, https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/sep/27/kwarteng-tax-cuts-will-force-significant-interest-rate-rises-by-bank-of-england[BoE's chief economist, Huw Pill] has warned “significant” increases in interest rates will have to be imposed by the central bank in response to tax cuts put forward by Kwasi Kwarteng in his mini-budget.[...][financial traders] are forecasting the Bank’s base rate rising to nearly 6% by spring 2023[...]Pill played down the chances of a rise in the base rate from the current level of 2.25% before the Bank’s next scheduled rate setting meeting in November, saying it needed to take a more “considered approach” recognising the limitations of monetary policy in “fine tuning shorter term developments”.
Various announcements and reports today suggest that its a dead cert now so I'm tightening my prediction from 92% to 100%

Traders unwound their bets on an unscheduled shift to higher rates, but stuck by their wagers on an extra-large rise at the central bank’s next meeting. Following the BoE’s announcement, markets were pricing in an increase to 3.75 per cent in November. The bank rate is expected to reach almost 6 per cent by May. - https://www.ft.com/content/c7f815b6-e7f2-43d2-b160-b7b3182e63b4
Extraordinary BoE statement today, although seemingly no urgent meeting being called just yet.
Responding to @ctsats research

... and suddenly, from Friday onwards, people started arguing and speculating for an emergency BoE meeting (before the scheduled one for November) as soon as this week, in order to hike the rates further...!

A minimum of 3% now looks odds on (via 0.5% and 0.25% increases) given the mini-budget statement released on Friday. However, there were plenty of forewarnings of the Governments intentions; the Bank of England could have responded more sharply with a pre-emptive 0.75% had it felt the urgency, but instead opted for a cautious response that looks well behind the curve. I now suspect that this will be the form they follow for the two meetings, keeping us in bin 4, as headline inflation should well peak in the interim, reducing the argument to raise much further this side of Christmas.
The mini-budget just about ensures high inflation.
Shifting this quite dramatically, at least temporarily.
I am still getting mixed signals on this.
All over the shot on this Q but city factoring in a 1% rise for Nov after that incredible budget, even .75% will v.likely lead to 3.25 and above.

Update to yesterdays forecast when BofE elected for 0.5% increase. My feeling was that the current rate hike would be a pre-emptive measure under known difficult conditions of a near-peak inflation (9.9%), the energy crisis, rising costs of living and huge Government borrowing. As from earlier forecasts I think they are cautiously pushing rates up while checking how this adds to increased costs such as mortgages etc. and I expect they’ll hope to see inflation start to stabilise, so they can repeat 0.5% again or vote for a lower increase if caution allows.
The energy price guarantee has made all the difference. Seems much less likely now that the rate will exceed 3.25% by year end. Two more .5% increases seem most likely now.

BofE has elected for 0.5% increase. The fact they chose 0.5% rather than 0.75% suggests to me that bin4 is still most likely; only three members voted for 0.75% (I thought it would be 4-6) and I think they are less likely to move to a larger increase than this having made two (relatively) big hikes in succession. As from earlier forecasts I think they are cautiously pushing up while checking how this adds to increased costs of living such as mortgages etc. I expect they’ll hope to see inflation start to stabilise, so they can reduce the next hike to 0.25%, or even hold for one of the two remaining dates.
Only raised by .5 today
The BoE raised the base rate by 0.5% today to 2.25%, which keeps it on course to be over 3.25% in December

Following the US Fed's .75 increase, I suspect we'll see at least 0.5 and possibly .75 or 1 (given the Bank of England is a good bit lower than the US right now). Given the US Fed is at 3-3.25 and signaling it will keep going, it seems increasingly likely that the Bank of England will get to that level by end of year.
Sterling under sustained pressure and BoE could raise by .75 tomorrow and match the Fed. This would make over 3.25% likely.
This twitter graph suggests it will be closer to 3.5%

Inflation has dipped fractionally below double figures (9.9% last month), in part due to falling petrol prices. And the recently confirmed £2,500 energy price cap should help help restrain rising inflation over winter. But core inflation is still rising (and at a 30 year high of 5.6%), and the ECB has just hiked rates 0.75% putting more pressure on the currency.

UK entering into recession but having high inflation and low unemployment, the untethered BoE will raise interest rates in the vain hope of getting inflation down through collapsing the housing market. Successive governments have enabled cheap borrowing and overheated the real estate sector with a series of initiatives and it is time for a price correction. Will quantitative easing continue?
Rate decision delayed after Queen's passing and Bailey was saying that recent energy policy announced by Truss will be taken into account.

Pressure will increase to raise rates further, but there are only three key meetings left before end of year, and in my view the maximum increase is 75 basis points at any stage. However I think the BofE will be reluctant to go this far and will aim for 50 or even 25 basis points per meeting if it feels it can. Many sources have already predicted ~3-3.5% by year end and I don't think there will be enough support to push beyond this before 2023. As @ctsats noted a higher rate is unlikely to stop supply-driven higher prices anyway and would have other negative knock-on consequences as well as reducing their options over winter.
Bank of England analysis of Investors suggest it will be well above 3.25%
Seems like at least some people at the BoE are pushing for a swift increase. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-09-05/bank-of-england-s-mann-calls-for-forceful-action-on-inflation
According to https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.dailyfx.com/forex/fundamental/central_bank_watch/2022/08/25/central-bank-watch-boe-ecb-interest-rate-expectations-update-august-25.html/amp
Updating my previous rationale (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1498139 ), as there seems to be some minority voices predicting a lower hike:

The recession and inflation is the worst its been for at least thirty years. The bank of England only have one lever they can play with and its the Base Rate. Historically they haven't increased it by more than 1 PC in each session. The Base Rate ought to be broadly comparable to the inflation rate, perhaps 2% lower, suggesting the correct Base Rate is between 6% to 12%. The Monetary Policy Committee have about three meetings left before 15th December, so the maximum they can realistically raise the base rate from the current level is 4.75%

Inflation is just far too high with a going rate above 10%. Any sensible central banker should raise the rate to above 10%, but that will not happen in this cray time. But BoE seems to be more determined than FED, so most probable, the rate will end aboe 3.25% by YE

The base rate is expected to finish the year above 3% and could peak at close to 4.1% in June 2023, based on interest-rate derivatives linked to the meeting dates of Threadneedle Street’s monetary policy committee. - The Guardian (Aug 23) https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/aug/23/bank-of-england-may-be-forced-to-raise-interest-rates-to-4-per-cent-2023-inflation

Rethinked this, BoE determined and ex committee members predicting 4% plus within six months. Looking at repossessions, quite extraordinary how low they are, even with cost of living crisis, caused in part due to a hyper inflated housing market.
UK CPI over 10%, forecast to go to 18.6% in the new year.
Inflation does not seem to have any other lever at present

Uncertainty around government policy. Will they cap prices this reducing inflation? How will BoE weigh up rising inflation with its nature (not driven by demand)? Will interest rates prove ineffective in reducing inflation, in fact increase mortgage costs, increasing inflation further?

OIS curve comfortably within range of 2.25% to 3.25%, very little time for an extraordinary event to prompt the BoE to take the sort of drastic action that would place benchmark rate outside of that range.
" Citi sees UK inflation hitting 18% peak in January"
September will see battle of wills between new PM and BoE with small increase
Three increases of 0.5 would put it at 3.25%.

Bank rates have tended upward recently to combat inflation. Right now, the rate is at 1.75% and as the US Fed increases rates, we would expect the Bank of England to do the same. Increasing over 0.5 seems a bit too high, but less than 3 and more than 2 seems like the best bet.
1) inflation is rising to around 13% by the 2022 end, BOE will act to stem demand
